docs.lead_paragraph: A day after successfully sustaining President Bush's veto of a bill to provide health insurance to 10 million children, Congressional Republicans remained in an uproar over comments made by Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California, who accused the Republicans, in a speech on the House floor, of sending American soldiers "to Iraq to get their heads blown off for the president's amusement."

headline.main: Stark's Remarks Set Off G.O.P. Lawmakers

docs.abstract: Congressional Republicans remained in an uproar, but the Representative Pete Stark is not backing away from his comments.
docs.snippet: Congressional Republicans remained in an uproar, but the Representative Pete Stark is not backing away from his comments.

docs.lead_paragraph: In his Web column today, Carl Hulse writes that while House Democrats might have lots of apparent advantages for the 2008 elections, some are cautioning against "irrational exuberance":
docs.abstract: The political environment looks good for Democrats now, but party strategists want to dispel any idea of a cakewalk.
docs.snippet: The political environment looks good for Democrats now, but party strategists want to dispel any idea of a cakewalk.

docs.lead_paragraph: The struggle to persuade enough Republicans to override the President's veto of a bill to expand the State Children's Health Insurance Program, or S-chip, fell short in the House of Representatives this afternoon.

headline.main: The S-Chip Roll Call–Who Voted to Override and Who Didn't

docs.abstract: The struggle to persuade enough Republicans to override the President's veto of a bill to expand the State Children's Health Insurance Program, or S-chip, fell short in the House of Representatives this afternoon. The vote to override was 273 to 156, or 13 votes short of the necessary two-thirds majority of those present and voting. [...]
docs.snippet: The struggle to persuade enough Republicans to override the President's veto of a bill to expand the State Children's Health Insurance Program, or S-chip, fell short in the House of Representatives this afternoon. The vote to override was 273 to 156,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Supporters of a children’s health insurance bill failed, as expected, to muster enough support in the House today to override President Bush’s veto.

headline.main: House Fails to Override Child Health Bill Veto
headline.print_headline: House Fails To Override Child Health Bill Veto

docs.snippet: Supporters of a children’s health insurance bill failed, as expected, to muster enough support in the House today to override President Bush’s veto.
